soc.message
Class StatusMessage

java.lang.Object
  soc.message.Message
      soc.message.StatusMessage
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
public class StatusMessage
extends Message

This is a text message that shows in a status box on the client. Used for "welcome" message at initial connect to game (follows JOINAUTH or JOINGAMEAUTH), or rejection if client can't join that game (or channel). Also used in AccountClient to tell the user if their change was made successfully.

Added in Version 1.1.06: Status value parameter (nonnegative integer). For backwards compatibility, the status value (integer getStatusValue() ) is not sent as a parameter, if it is 0. (In JSettlers older than 1.1.06, it is always 0.) Earlier versions simply printed the entire message as text, without trying to parse anything.

Author:
Robert S. Thomas
See Also:
Serialized Form

Field Detail

SV_OK

public static final int SV_OK
Status value constants. SV_OK = 0 : Welcome, OK to connect. SV_NOT_OK_GENERIC = 1 : Generic "not OK" status value. Other specific status value constants are given here. If any are added, do not change or remove the numeric values of earlier ones.

Since:
1.1.06
See Also:
Constant Field Values

SV_NOT_OK_GENERIC

public static final int SV_NOT_OK_GENERIC
SV_NOT_OK_GENERIC = 1 : Generic "not OK" status value. This is given to the client if a more specific value does not apply, or if the client's version is older than the version where the more specific value was introduced.

Since:
1.1.06
See Also:
Constant Field Values

Constant Field Values

SV_NAME_IN_USE

public static final int SV_NAME_IN_USE
This name is already logged in = 4. In version 1.1.08 and higher, a "take over" option is used for reconnect when a client loses connection, and server doesn't realize it. A new connection can "take over" the name after a minute's timeout. For actual timeouts, see SOCServer.checkNickname.

Since:
1.1.06
See Also:

SV_NEWGAME_OPTION_UNKNOWN

public static final int SV_NEWGAME_OPTION_UNKNOWN
New game requested with game options, but some are not recognized by the server = 9

Since:

See Also:
SOCServer.handleNEWGAMEWITHOPTIONSREQUEST(soc.server.genericServer.StringConnection, soc.message.NewGameWithOptionsRequest), Constant Field Values

SV_NEWGAME_OPTION_VALUE_TOONEW

public static final int SV_NEWGAME_OPTION_VALUE_TOONEW
New game requested with game options, but this option or value is too new for the client to handle = 10

Format of this status text is:
Status string with error message SEP2 game name SEP2 option keyname with problem SEP2 option keyname with problem (if more than one) ...

Since:
1.1.07
See Also:
SOCServer.handleNEWGAMEWITHOPTIONSREQUEST(soc.server.genericServer.StringConnection, soc.message.NewGameWithOptionsRequest), Constant Field Values

SV_NEWGAME_NAME_TOO_LONG

public static final int SV_NEWGAME_NAME_TOO_LONG
New game requested, but name of game or player is too long = 13. The text returned with this status shall indicate the max permitted length.

1.1.07

MSG_SV_NEWGAME_NAME_TOO_LONG

public static final java.lang.String MSG_SV_NEWGAME_NAME_TOO_LONG
Text for server or client to present: New game requested, but game name or player name is too long. Maximum permitted length is appended to this message after the trailing ":".

Since:
1.1.07

Constructor Detail

StatusMessage

public StatusMessage(java.lang.String st)
Create a StatusMessage message, with status value 0 (SV_OK).

Parameters:
st - the status message text. For this constructor, since status value is 0, may not contain Message.sep2 characters. This will cause parsing to fail on the remote end.

StatusMessage

public StatusMessage(int sv,
                     java.lang.String st)
Create a StatusMessage message, with a nonzero value.

Parameters:
sv - status value (from constants defined here, such as SV_OK)
st - the status message text. If sv is nonzero, you may embed Message.sep2 characters in your string, and they will be passed on for the receiver to parse.
Since:
1.1.06

the status message text. Is allowed to contain Message.sep2 characters.

public static java.lang.String toCmd(int sv,
                                     java.lang.String st)
STATUSMESSAGE sep [svalue sep2] status

Parameters:
sv - the status value; if 0 or less, is not output. Should be a constant such as SV_OK.
st - the status message text. If sv is nonzero, you may embed Message.sep2 characters in your string, and they will be passed on for the receiver to parse.
Returns:
the command string
See Also:
toCmd(int, int, String)

toCmd

public static java.lang.String toCmd(int sv,
                                     int cliVers,
                                     java.lang.String st)
STATUSMESSAGE sep [svalue sep2] status -- includes backwards compatibility. Calls statusValidAtVersion(int, int). if sv isn't recognized in that version, will send SV_NOT_OK_GENERIC instead.

Parameters:
sv - the status value; if 0 or less, is not output. Should be a constant such as SV_OK.
cliVers - Client's version, same format as Version.versionNumber()
st - the status message text. If sv is nonzero, you may embed Message.sep2 characters in your string, and they will be passed on for the receiver to parse.
Returns:
the command string
Since:
1.1.07

statusValidAtVersion

public static boolean statusValidAtVersion(int statusValue,
                                           int cliVersion)
Is this status value defined in this version? If not, SV_NOT_OK_GENERIC should be sent instead.

Parameters:
statusValue - status value (from constants defined here, such as SV_OK)
cliVersion - Client's version, same format as Version.versionNumber(); below 1.1.06, only 0 (SV_OK) is allowed. If cliVersion > ourVersion, will act as if cliVersion == ourVersion.
Since:
1.1.07

parseDataStr

public static StatusMessage parseDataStr(java.lang.String s)
Parse the command String into a StatusMessage message. If status is nonzero, you may embed Message.sep2 characters in your string, and they will be passed on to the receiver.

Parameters:
s - the String to parse
Returns:
a StatusMessage message, or null of the data is garbled
